Both Freud and Marx move me in their engagement with ethics.
It was finally my contact with the ethical philosopher Bimal Krishna Matilal that allowed me to make room for Freud in my intellectual world.

Professor Matilal argued that nineteenth-century Indologists were basically correct in estimating that India had no tradition of moral philosophy in the Western European sense.'0 But they had not been able to grasp either the Indic tradition of rational critique or the tradition of practical ethics in India. According to Matilal, the latter was based on the reading of narrative instantiations of ethical problems. We read some of the Mahabharata together in this way. I realized that this way of doing rather than exclusively talking about doing (the other is also an ethical decision, of course-this is at the root of my unease with the use of psychoanalysis in cultural critique) ethics was a rather widespread, rather global, phenomenon, not confined to non-European cultures. It had been ranked as "popular" by most high-cultural European-model moral philosoph ical systems. (I am not speaking, of course, of diagnosing story lines as formal allegories, drawing morals from parables, or attention to the "moral dimension" of fiction.) Jon Elster's Ulysses and the Sirens, which I was reading at the time, seemed an example of moral philosophizing on that "popular" model." And psychoanalysis, as a challenge to systematic moral philosophy, had certainly read re ceived narratives and the sequentially constructed narratives of analysands as instantiations of socioethical problems. As a cultural critic rather than a clinical practitioner, I was not obliged to take the conclusions as scientific system. As a being in ethics, I could share them as malleable situational lessons.

Professor Matilal also suggested that the moral dilemma was the most important terrain for the exercise of this type of practical ethics as encountered in the Indic tradition. Freud's recognition of the aporia between terminable and interminable analyses, and Der rida's thinking of ethics as the experience of the impossible, resonated with this suggestion."2 Derrida's work is also a critique of traditional European systematic moral philosophy, after all. Further, this par ticular privileging of the aporia in the field of ethical decision seemed quite apposite to the tale of Narcissus. As I will attempt to show in my reading of Ovid, it is a tale of the aporia between self knowledge and knowledge for others.
highlights.note: Professor Matilal said that nineteenth-century Western scholars were partly right to think India didn’t have moral philosophy like Europe’s, but they missed how Indian thinkers used reasoned critique and practical ethics. In India, ethics was often taught by telling and discussing stories that show moral problems, as when we read parts of the Mahabharata together; this way of learning—doing ethics through stories and examples rather than abstract systems—actually happens in many cultures, not only non-European ones, and European high-culture philosophers often dismissed it as merely “popular.” I’m not talking about treating stories as simple allegories or just finding morals in fiction, but about using real narrative situations to think through ethical choices. Books like Jon Elster’s Ulysses and the Sirens and psychoanalysis do something similar by reading stories or life accounts as examples of social and ethical problems; as a cultural critic I don’t have to accept their conclusions as scientific truth, but I can treat them as flexible lessons about ethical life. Matilal also thought that moral dilemmas are the main place where this practical, story-based ethics appears in Indian thought; thinkers like Freud and Derrida—who highlighted irresolvable tensions in analysis and called ethics the experience of the impossible—agree with focusing on these unsolvable knots. Derrida also criticized traditional systematic European moral philosophy, and this focus on irresolvable ethical problems fits well with the story of Narcissus, which I will read as a tale about the impossible gap between knowing oneself and knowing others.

highlights.note: Here, the mother is described only as an "envelope" — a simple container with no life or story of her own, as Luce Irigaray says. But in Ovid’s tale, Liriope’s womb has its own past. It ends up surrounding Narcissus because of an earlier violent act: the river god Cephisus forced himself on her. This act is a kind of sexual violence by a partly divine being that the other gods accept without political consequence. The roles of Tiresias and Echo in the story are woven into a larger pattern of punishment and reward that shapes the whole account.

Q: how much of this is academic masterbation

A: Some readers will call parts of Spivak's "Echo" academic masturbation—dense theoretical maneuvers, repetitions, and close readings that can feel self-referential—but that style also aims to do political and ethical work (rescuing Echo, exposing power/voice asymmetries). Whether it’s masturbatory vs. generative depends on your tolerance for dense deconstructive prose and whether you value its subtle political claims.

Deconstructive Lever: The deconstructive lever is a philosophical tool metaphor used to describe a method of analyzing texts, ideas, or systems by applying pressure to an assumed hinge point to reveal hidden contradictions and power structures. It emphasizes close reading, attention to language, and the way meanings shift when foundational terms or oppositions are questioned. The metaphor shows how small shifts in interpretation can overturn apparent stability and open new possibilities for thought and critique.

highlights.note: Paradoxical self-negation in desire: Paradoxical self-negation in desire refers to the phenomenon where a person's wanting or longing for something involves a form of denying or negating themselves in the process. This means that the desire can lead to a conflict between what one wishes for and their current sense of self or identity. It is often discussed in philosophy and psychology to explain how desires can sometimes undermine or challenge a person's existing values or beliefs.

highlights.note: Simulacrum of the Analyst in Psychoanalytic Practice: The simulacrum of the analyst refers to a concept where the analyst's role is represented or imitated in therapeutic settings to help the patient project and explore unconscious thoughts and feelings. This idea emphasizes the importance of the analyst's position as a symbolic figure rather than just a person, allowing the patient to engage with their inner world through this representation. It is used to deepen understanding and facilitate the psychoanalytic process by creating a space for reflection and insight.

If the ever-renewed narcissus flower is a "natural monument" to the fulfillment of Narcissus's desire-as-punishment out of this world, the lithography of Echo's bony remains merely points to the risk of response. It has no identity proper to itself. It is obliged to be imperfectly and interceptively responsive to another's desire, if only for the self separation of speech. It is the catachresis of response as such.
highlights.note:
The idea of performance is spread out randomly, not because of a stubborn choice like Narcissus made. The narcissus flower, which keeps growing again and again, is like a natural reminder of Narcissus's wish that became a kind of punishment, something outside the normal world. On the other hand, the image of Echo’s bones only shows the danger in trying to respond. Echo doesn’t have her own identity. She has to respond in a way that is incomplete and interrupted, always reflecting someone else’s desire, just to keep speech separated from herself. This is an example of how responding can sometimes be awkward or forced.

Catachresis in Linguistic Response Theory: Catachresis is a figure of speech where a word is used in an unusual or incorrect way to create a new meaning or effect. In Linguistic Response Theory, catachresis is studied as a way people respond creatively to language challenges by bending or breaking standard rules. This helps researchers understand how language evolves and how meaning can be flexible in communication.

highlights.note: A rebellion that can’t really happen. Each speaker—the one who shouts too loudly or the one who talks too quickly—is set free. The “I” of the first person, full of anger and rough coughing sounds in the throat. Every woman, hurting deep inside, can never truly be understood: in usual, repeated phrases, the voice shares its heavy feelings, which are then softened by others listening together. The same goes for joy or happiness shared in stories; all these ways of speaking are like performances meant to slowly unravel a fate that you have to figure out.
